body.p: This topic is designed to train you on how to setup your Oxygen editor to effectively work in DITA.
First, make sure you are in the DITA perspective by clicking the DITA Perspective icon in the top-right side of the window.
Next, ensure you are in Author Mode by clicking the Author tab near the bottom-left of the window.

The next step is to ensure your Attributes and Elements windows are docked in your editor window. This allows you to quickly see a list of allowed elements and make any necessary edits to attributes. Typically, these windows are automatically docked to the right side of the editor window. If they are not:

ol.li: Select Elements. The elements window should now appear.
Select Attributes. The attributes window should now appear.

body.p: How you decide to organize your editor window is up to you. Provided below is a sample way of organizing the editor window with the DITA Maps Manager docked to the left side of the window, the editor in the middle, and the Attributes and Elements windows docked to the right side.

The final thing to do is to decide on how you want to view (or not view) element tags in the editing window. Typically, it is best to turn tags on in some form to be able to clearly see where element bounds begin and end. This allows you to accurately edit elements and know where to insert new ones.
Clicking the Tags button in the upper-left of the editing window gives you many options for displaying element tags.

The Full Tags with Attributes option is not recommended as it displays lots of extra information that isn't needed. The Full Tags option displays both block and inline tags, providing a good view of all active elements in your document. There are also options to display just block or inline tags, or to simply view a symbol indicating an element bound without displaying the actual element type. Experiment with the view options and decide which is write for your editing habits.
